article.headline: USC 83, California 66
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Now that Southern California has a couple conference wins to its credit, the Trojans are looking to bigger and better things. Lodrick Stewart scored seven of his 23 points during a decisive second-half run, and the Trojans beat short-handed California 83-66 Thursday night. Stewart, a sophomore averaging nearly 15 points, has scored 20 or more six times this season and eight in his career. He also had season-high totals of seven rebounds and four steals as the Trojans (9-9, 2-5 Pac-10), who won their second straight following a five-game losing streak. "We just needed one win. The win against Arizona State brought everybody's confidence back," Stewart said, referring to a 98-94 victory at ASU last Saturday. USC won big despite falling behind by 11 points in the early going. "I thought we came out real lethargic," interim coach Jim Saia said. "I had a feeling about it. For whatever reason, we need to generate our own energy. We just weren't a smart basketball team. "We shot 53 percent in the second half. When I see we shoot 53 percent in the second half, especially at home, I feel like we have a good chance to win." Stewart made a 3-pointer and two baskets; Pruitt added six points, and Rory O'Neil scored four during a 17-4 spurt that gave the Trojans a 61-49 lead with 11½ minutes remaining. The Bears weren't closer than 10 points after that. `We can still finish No. 1. Anything's possible," Stewart said. "Our confidence was down. Coach Saia never gave up on us. We had fun tonight." Stewart shot 7-of-9 including 4-of-4 from 3-point range. "Lodrick is a phenomenal shooter," Saia said. "He's a gamer with a beautiful left-handed stroke. He's getting better on defense." Stewart pointed to defense and "the little things" as the key factors in the game. "Little things add up," he said. Errick Craven, still recovering from a sprained right ankle, scored 12 points and freshman Gabe Pruitt added 11 points and four assists for USC. Jeff McMillan had 11 rebounds to go with eight points for the Trojans. Marquise Kately scored 12 points for California (8-8, 1-5), which lost its fourth in a row and fifth in six games following a 7-3 start. Kately went scoreless in two of his previous three games and shot 0-for-8 in a 74-58 loss to Stanford last Saturday. David Paris added 11 points, Eric Vierneisel had 10 and freshman Kevin Langford scored a career-high nine for the Golden Bears. The win was just USC's fifth in the last 16 games between the schools. The Bears played without Richard Midgley and Dominic McGuire. Midgley, averaging a team-leading 15.1 points, sat out because of a sprained right shoulder. McGuire, averaging 6.3 points and 4.9 rebounds, was benched for violating a team rule. "We've got to play the hand that's dealt us," Cal coach Ben Braun said. "It's not fun, but I'm not one to make excuses. We've just got to put it together and get our guys back healthy." Cal, using a lineup of players who had combined for 14 of a possible 75 starts previously and averaging 26.1 points, jumped out to a 14-3 lead. Paris had six points and the other four starters two each at that stage. O'Neil made a 3-pointer to trigger a 17-5 run, giving the Trojans a 20-19 lead. Stewart added two more 3-pointers during the spurt. Neither team led by more than four points during the remainder of the first half, which ended with the Bears on top 35-33. Cal led 45-44 when USC began its decisive run. "We didn't do a good job of denying them second-half opportunities," Braun said. "We lost the mental edge that we had in the first half. We had trouble getting back in transition, but fatigue is going to be part of any game when you're short-handed." Cal shot 15-of-29 to USC's 9-of-27 in the opening 20 minutes, but the Trojans were 11-of-13 from the foul line while the Bears were 3-of-8. USC shot 17-of-32 (53.1 percent) in the second half to finish at 44.1 percent. Cal shot 42.3 percent after halftime to finish at 47.3 percent. But the Bears were just 10-of-24 from the foul line while the Trojans were 21-of-26.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
